context: [1] In comparison with the apo structure, the active site shows very few changes. [2] The only notable change is in the side chain conformation of residue Met436 whose CÏµ atom rotates about 90Â° to accommodate the bromine atom of compound 1 (Fig.Â 3B). [3] Here, we noticed that Phe432 in the compound 1 cocrystal structure adopts the same conformation as in the apo form. [4] When compared with the reported structures of arachidonyl inhibitor MAFP in rat FAAH (PDB code: 1MT5) and piperidine-urea compound PF-750 in a humanized rat FAAH chimera (PDB code: 2VYA) (â€“), compound 1 shows the same covalent mode of inactivation, in which the urea carbonyl is attacked by Ser241, despite the evident difference in the chemical structures of these covalent adducts. [5] Furthermore, the adducts from these ligands, attached to the catalytic Ser241, follow a similar path toward the united portion of the MAC and ABP and make extensive van der Waals contacts with numerous hydrophobic residues in this proximal portion of the active site. [1] In summary, the structural data revealed that compound 1 inhibits FAAH through urea carbonyl acylation of the catalytic nucleophile Ser241 with the 2-fluoroaniline moiety as the leaving group (Fig.Â 3C). [2] Compound 1 behaves as a suicide substrate inhibitor.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea and piperidine are related through their involvement in the structure and function of a compound that inhibits fatty acid amide hydrolase (FAAH). The urea moiety is part of a piperidine-urea compound (PF-750) that interacts with the enzyme's active site, where the urea carbonyl is acylated by the catalytic serine residue. This indicates a significant functional relationship between the two in the context of enzyme inhibition.
